text: The disciplined mind leads to happiness, and the undisciplined mind leads to suffering.
You have the right to work, but for the work's sake only. You have no right to the fruits of work.
Calmness, gentleness, silence, self-restraint, and purity: these are the disciplines of the mind.
For one who has conquered his mind, a mind is best of friends, but for one who has failed to do so, a mind is the greatest enemy.
Perseverance in seeking the knowledge of the Supreme Spirit, and perception of the gain that comes from knowledge of the truth.
The disciplined mind is free of lust, free of fear, and free of anger.
Seek refuge in the attitude of detachment and you will amass the wealth of spiritual awareness.
One who sees inaction in action, and action in inaction, is intelligent among men.
When meditation is mastered, the mind is unwavering like the flame of a lamp in a windless place.
Do not get angry or harm any living creature, but be compassionate and gentle; show good will to all.
Sever the ignorant doubt in your heart with the sword of self-knowledge. Observe your discipline. Arise.
